docs.lead_paragraph: On train platforms and on Main Street, New Yorkers are worried and ready for change they just wonder whether politicians are up to the task.

docs.lead_paragraph: PRICE DROP FOR NEW HOMES -- Home builders, struggling to keep ahead in a weakening market, cut prices and offered a variety of other discounts in September to help sell their newly constructed houses, the latest government and industry statistics show. [Page C1.] CONGRESS TO REVIEW S.E.C. The Securities and Exchange Commission, under scrutiny for its handling of an insider-trading case involving the prominent hedge fund Pequot Capital and the influential Wall Street executive John J. Mack, above, will be the subject of a broad review by the investigative arm of Congress, the Government Accountability Office. [C1.] DELAY IN TAX COLLECTION -- The commissioner of Internal Revenue ordered his agency to delay collecting back taxes from Hurricane Katrina victims until after the Nov. 7 elections and the holiday season, saying he did so in part to avoid negative publicity. [A1.] LONDON AS FINANCIAL CAPITAL -- Even as the Dow Jones industrial average climbs to new highs and Wall Street companies report robust profits, by some measures New York's long-held crown as the financial capital of the world may be slipping, and London is gaining. [C1.] FLOCKING TO FORT WORTH -- Under golf courses, schools, parks, libraries, airports and dozens of neighborhoods, some of the nation's leading independent energy companies are scouring Fort Worth, Tex., in search of the best locations to recover one of the largest concentrations of natural gas in the United States. [C1.] MICROSOFT BEATS EXPECTATIONS -- Microsoft reported solid quarterly results that slightly surpassed Wall Street expectations, with sales growth driven by its Xbox game business and software for server computers. Both sales and profit rose 11 percent. [C3.] OIL GIANTS POST SOLID RESULTS -- The oil giants Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell reported stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings, showing resilience in the face of recently falling oil and gas prices and rising costs. [C3.] LAWSUIT OVER LIFE SETTLEMENTS -- Coventry First, one of the largest purchasers of life settlements -- arrangements where investors buy life insurance policies owned by the elderly and ill, hoping to earn when sellers' demise -- was sued by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, who accused the company of bid-rigging and other types of fraud in acquiring more than $3.6 billion worth of life insurance policies. [C3.] LEGAL SERVICES OUTSOURCED -- The law firm Clifford Chance is set to announce that it will move big chunks of its administrative functions like accounting and technological support to a facility in Delhi, India, by next spring. [C3.] PLAVIX HURT BY CANADIAN RIVAL -- Still reeling from a generic assault on its top-selling product, Plavix, Bristol-Myers Squibb said it lost up to $600 million in sales of the drug to a Canadian rival during the third quarter, accounting for part of a 65 percent decline in earnings. [C4.] STROKE DRUG FAILS IN TRIAL -- An experimental drug called XNY-059 that AstraZeneca had hoped could protect the brain from the damage caused by a stroke has failed in a large clinical trial, the company said. [C4.] SCARY ADS FOR HALLOWEEN -- In the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, many advertising campaigns for Halloween were significantly toned down. Five years on, the horror quotient is being dialed back up to typical levels, replete with all manner of macabre things that go bump in the night. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.] AIRBUS ORDER DELAYED -- Virgin Atlantic Airways said it had decided to postpone its order for six Airbus A380 jets by four years, making it the first airline to step back from its commitment to the troubled twin-deck plane and signaling the potential for more trouble. The A380, a 555-seat plane, has been plagued by major production problems, and Airbus has said that the delays could wipe $6 billion off the profit of its parent, European Aeronautic Defense and Space, over four years. [C7.] VIETNAM'S W.T.O. BID APPROVED -- Trade negotiators in Geneva approved the terms of Vietnam's admission to the World Trade Organization, but the biggest winners from its entry will probably not be American. They will probably be European and Asian. [C7.] SHARES MARCH HIGHER -- Stocks extended their rally, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index toward its best month since 2003, as lower oil prices improved the outlook for companies sensitive to consumer spending. [C8.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Ford Motor, which this week reported its biggest loss in 14 years, will almost double its purchase of China-made parts this year to cut production costs. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Raytheon's third-quarter profit rose 41 percent on increased sales of aircraft and systems to coordinate battle operations. (AP) Aetna, one of the nation's largest health insurers, said that third-quarter profit rose 28 percent, driven in part by aggressive campaigns that added more than 700,000 customers in the last year. (AP) Kellogg said third-quarter profit rose 2.5 percent, helped by sales of new snacks and Eggo waffles. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) The US Airways Group, formed last year from the merger of US Airways and America West Airlines, posted a third-quarter net loss after fuel hedging and merger-related costs. (REUTERS)

docs.lead_paragraph: An influential government advisory panel recommended that Americans 60 and older be vaccinated against shingles, an excruciatingly painful rash caused by the same virus that causes chickenpox. The recommendations of the panel, the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, are usually accepted by federal health officials, and they influence insurance companies’ decisions on which vaccinations to cover. No vaccine was available until May, when the Food and Drug Administration licensed Zostavax, made by Merck & Company. The vaccine is a modified version of Merck’s chickenpox vaccine for children, with a live virus that is 14 times more potent.

docs.lead_paragraph: Under the New Jersey Supreme Court's decision, same-sex couples will soon be granted rights like those of married couples, ranging from the very narrow to those that help define what a family is. Among other things, gay and lesbian couples are to be allowed survivor benefits under the state's workers' compensation system, as well as state tax deductions for spousal medical expenses and exemptions from fees for real estate transfers between spouses.

headline.main: Court Outlines Rights It Says Gay Couples Are Due

docs.abstract: New Jersey Supreme Court decision on same-sex marriage does not grant terming of same-sex unions as marriages but outlines benefits under constitutional protection of equality in several areas of law (M)
docs.snippet: Under the New Jersey Supreme Court’s decision, same-sex couples will soon be granted rights like those of married couples.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Economix column in Business Day on Oct. 18 that compared medical insurance in the United States to other countries referred incorrectly to the 47 million uninsured people in the United States. The figure includes noncitizens; they are not all Americans. (The error was repeated in a front-page article yesterday about hospitals that offer free basic care to the uninsured.)
docs.abstract: Correction of Economix column Oct 18 comparing medical insurance in United States to other countries; 47 million uninsured people in US includes noncitizens
